intro: Acer laetum var. cultratum, commonly known as the Cut-leaf maple, is a deciduous tree native to the mountainous regions of central and southern China. It is characterized by its distinctive, finely serrated leaves that resemble a blade, giving it its common name. The tree typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters and has a broad, spreading crown. Its leaves are bright green in summer and turn vibrant yellow in autumn, adding ornamental value to landscapes. The plant prefers well-drained soils and is often cultivated for its aesthetic appeal in gardens and parks.
